summary: A 2019 New York Magazine article examining the business and personal ties between Jeffrey Epstein and his brother Mark Epstein, focusing on their interconnected real estate ventures and the use of Mark's condominium building to house Epstein's associates and alleged victims. The article raises questions about the extent of their relationship despite Mark's public denials.

connections.description: Brothers who grew up together. The article explores their opaque adult relationship and interconnected business ties through real estate.

Mark Epstein stated in a deposition that Trump flew on Jeffrey's plane numerous times and they were "good friends."
Jeffrey managed Wexner's assets through J. Epstein & Co. Mark purchased a condominium building from Wexner.
Barrett was in charge of running Mark's real-estate business, Ossa Properties.
Barrett was also an asset manager for Jeffrey's company, J. Epstein & Co.

keyFacts: Mark Epstein's real-estate business, Ossa Properties, was linked to Jeffrey Epstein's company, J. Epstein & Co., through shared asset manager Jonathan Barrett.

Mark Epstein owned the majority of units in a condominium at 301 East 66th Street, purchased from Leslie Wexner, where Jeffrey Epstein allegedly housed friends, employees, associates, and models connected to his MC2 agency.
A 2010 sworn statement from a former MC2 employee alleged that MC2 models were victims of Jeffrey Epstein's underage sex-trafficking ring.

Despite Mark Epstein's public denials of a business connection and claims of a "mistake," the article details multiple points of contact, including Mark offering his Florida home for Jeffrey's bond in 2019.

The article highlights the opacity of the Epstein brothers' adult relationship, contrasting Mark's recent statements with Jeffrey's 2009 legal filing which stated he had "no known immediate family" and "no meaningful family ties."
